description: Practical Godot glossary covering core vocabulary for Godot 4.x development

terms.definition: A game/app folder with project.godot at the root.
A reusable "thing" made of nodes (like a prefab). Saved as .tscn / .scn.
The basic building block. Everything in a scene tree is a node.
The runtime hierarchy of nodes (your running world).
The engine object managing your running scenes; accessible via get_tree().
A saved scene you can instantiate at runtime.
Creating a runtime copy of a scene (Godot 4 uses instantiate()).
A node's "scene ownership" for saving/exporting parts of a tree into a scene file.
A node can be marked unique for %NodeName access (Godot 4 feature).
The game engine software that runs your game (e.g., Godot, Unity, Unreal).
A collection of tools and libraries that provide structure for game development.
The period when your game is running and executing code.
The process of compiling and packaging your game for distribution.
Converting source code into executable machine code.
A game entity that can perform actions (common in some engines).
A container for components in component-based architectures (e.g., Unity).
A modular piece of functionality attached to an entity or object.
A manager that processes entities or components in a game architecture.
A unique identifier for an object in Entity Component System (ECS) architecture.
An architectural pattern separating data (components) from logic (systems) via entities.
A reusable template for creating game objects or scenes.
The parent-child relationship structure of game objects or nodes.
The top-level parent in a hierarchy with no parent itself.
An object or node that has a parent in the hierarchy.
An object or node that contains children in the hierarchy.
Position, rotation, and scale of an object in 2D or 3D space.
The sequence of events from object creation to destruction.
The main game loop that runs every frame to update game state.
A single iteration of the game loop or physics simulation.
Time elapsed since the last frame, used for frame-rate independent calculations.
The process of setting up an object or system when it's first created.
Base class, no transform.
2D transform (position/rotation/scale).
UI node (layout + anchors/margins).
3D transform.
Base for 2D drawables (Node2D + Control inherit this).
A render target (main screen is a viewport; can make your own).
Draw UI/2D on a separate layer (good for HUD).
Data object that can be saved/loaded (.tres, .res). Materials, scripts, animations, etc.
Text vs binary resource formats.
Common resource types.
UI styling resource for Control nodes.
Godot's asset import pipeline (textures, audio, models).
Godot's built-in scripting language.
Supported via .NET (depending on your export setup).
C++ extensions system (replaces old GDNative).
Script inheritance (extends Node2D, etc.).
Exposes a variable in the Inspector.
Assign after the node enters the scene tree (when children exist).
Event system (emit/subscribe).
A function reference you can store/pass.
Godot's dynamic value type (can hold many kinds of data).
Vector2, Vector3, Transform2D, Transform3D, Color, Rect2, etc.
Constructor-like initialization.
Called when added to the scene tree.
Called when node + children are ready.
Every frame (render frame).
Fixed timestep (physics).
Raw input events.
Input not consumed by UI/others.
Decoupled communication.
Tag nodes to broadcast calls (get_tree().call_group()).
A scene/script loaded once and globally accessible.
Kinematic-style movement with move_and_slide().
Physics-simulated body (forces/impulses).
Doesn't move (walls/floors).
Detection/overlaps/triggers.
Defines collision geometry.
Friction/bounce.
"What am I?" (layer) and "what do I collide with?" (mask).
Queries for collision checks.
Advanced physics queries API.
A shape that defines collision boundaries for physics detection.
Collision shape that detects when something is hit.
Collision shape that detects when something takes damage.
A physics body that responds to forces and collisions.
A body moved manually by code rather than physics simulation.
A physics body that doesn't move (walls, floors, obstacles).
A physics body that moves and responds to forces.
A line query to detect collisions along a path.
A swept volume query to detect collisions along a path.
Detecting when two collision shapes intersect without physics response.
A collision shape that detects overlaps but doesn't cause physics collisions.
When two physics bodies come into contact.
When objects overlap into each other (should be resolved by physics).
The process of separating overlapping physics bodies.
Bounciness coefficient; how much energy is retained in collisions.
The rebounding effect when objects collide.
Resistance to sliding when surfaces are in contact.
The weight of a physics body, affecting how forces affect it.
Air resistance or damping that slows down movement.
A limitation on how physics bodies can move relative to each other.
A connection between two physics bodies that limits their movement.
Rotational force applied to a physics body.
When a physics body stops moving and is deactivated for performance.
Activating a sleeping physics body when it needs to move again.
Continuous collision detection for fast-moving objects to prevent tunneling.
A single update of the physics simulation at a fixed timestep.
Rules that determine which objects can collide with each other.
3D equivalents of 2D physics bodies.
3D collision geometry.
A visible 3D mesh.
3D camera and lighting nodes.
Pathfinding.
Plays keyframed animations.
Blending/state machines for animations.
Code-driven interpolation ("animate this value over time").
Bone-based animation.
A specific point in time where an animation property has a defined value.
A visual representation of animation over time.
Smoothly transitioning between two animations.
A system for blending multiple animations based on parameters.
The change from one animation state to another.
An animation that repeats continuously.
Movement data extracted from animation to drive character movement.
The skeleton structure that controls how a model deforms.
The bone hierarchy that controls character deformation.
A single element in a skeleton that influences mesh deformation.
A system that calculates bone rotations to reach a target position.
Animating bones by directly setting their rotations.
A mathematical function that controls animation acceleration/deceleration.
A single animation sequence with a start and end time.
The rate at which an animation plays (1.0 = normal, 2.0 = double speed).
A marker in an animation that triggers code at a specific time.
A signal or callback triggered at a specific point in an animation.
Applying an animation from one skeleton to another with different proportions.
A specific arrangement of bone positions and rotations.
Selectively enabling or disabling animation on specific bones or layers.
Stacking multiple animations on top of each other (e.g., walking + waving).
An animation that modifies another animation rather than replacing it.
Synchronizing multiple animations to play at the same rate or phase.
Named actions (recommended).
Query actions.
InputEventKey, InputEventMouseButton, etc.
A configuration that maps physical inputs to logical actions.
A named input action (e.g., "jump", "move") that can be bound to different keys.
A continuous input value ranging from -1 to 1 (e.g., joystick, trigger).
Allowing players to change which keys/buttons trigger actions.
Checking input state every frame rather than responding to events.
A controller input device (Xbox, PlayStation, etc.).
Keyboard input device.
Mouse input device for cursor and button input.
Touch screen input for mobile and tablet devices.
A complex touch input pattern (swipe, pinch, etc.).
A multiplier that adjusts how much input affects movement or rotation.
A function that maps raw input to output, often used for smoothing or non-linear response.
Haptic feedback from controllers (rumble).
Which UI element or window currently receives input.
Locking the mouse cursor to the center of the screen (common in FPS games).
Capturing all input events, preventing them from reaching other systems.
A gesture requiring two quick taps/clicks in succession.
Pressing and maintaining an input for a duration.
How UI positions/sizes relative to parent.
Auto-layout (HBox/VBox/GridContainer, etc.).
Keyboard/controller navigation.
Per-node styling adjustments.
Draw a texture in 2D.
Frame animation (SpriteFrames resource).
Grid-based level building (Godot 4 TileMap workflow).
Particle systems.
Custom GPU code for effects.
Draw order controls.
A 2D image displayed in the game world.
An image file used for rendering surfaces.
A single texture containing multiple smaller images (sprite sheet).
Texture coordinates that map vertices to positions in a texture.
GPU program that controls how surfaces are rendered.
A resource that defines surface properties (color, shininess, shader, etc.).
A 3D model made of vertices, edges, and faces.
A point in 3D space that defines the shape of a mesh.
A pixel being processed by a fragment shader.
A texture that adds surface detail by simulating bumps and grooves.
A pre-calculated texture storing lighting information for static geometry.
Base lighting that affects all surfaces equally.
A light source that shines in one direction (like the sun).
A light source that radiates in all directions from a point (like a lightbulb).
A texture that stores depth information for rendering shadows.
A post-processing effect that makes bright areas glow.
A post-processing effect that blurs fast-moving objects.
Visual effects applied after the main scene is rendered.
A single rendering operation that draws part of the scene.
A command sent to the GPU to render geometry.
Skipping rendering of objects that aren't visible.
The viewable area of the camera (pyramid-shaped in 3D).
When one object blocks another from view.
The ability to see through an object (alpha blending).
The transparency channel of a color or texture.
A layer that determines draw order for 2D sprites.
A value that determines draw order (higher = drawn on top).
Sorting sprites by Y position to create depth illusion.
An effect where distant objects move slower than close ones, creating depth.
Small visual elements used for effects (smoke, sparks, etc.).
Graphics Processing Unit; hardware that handles rendering.
Level of Detail; using simpler models at greater distances.
Pre-generated smaller versions of textures for distance rendering.
The number of pixels in width and height of a display or texture.
Simple INI-like save.
Read/write files.
Common data format.
You can save custom Resources too (great for item databases).
Where you edit node properties.
Panels (Scene, FileSystem, Inspector, etc.).
Scene tree view of the running game.
Editor helpers for transforms/handles.
Packaging for Windows/macOS/Linux/Web/Android/iOS.
Time since last frame (for frame-rate independent motion).
Physics tick rate.
Rendering optimization.
Built-in performance tools.
Restrict a value to a minimum and maximum range.
Linear interpolation between two values over time.
Find the interpolation factor (0-1) for a value between two bounds.
Map a value from one range to another range.
Move a value toward a target by a fixed amount.
Convert a vector to unit length (magnitude of 1) while preserving direction.
Calculate the distance between two points.
Mathematical operation on vectors; useful for angles, projections, and direction checks.
The rotation or direction between two points, typically measured in radians or degrees.
Wrap a value around when it exceeds bounds (e.g., 361° becomes 1°).
Round a value to the nearest multiple of a step size.
Smooth acceleration/deceleration curves for animations and movement.
Rate of change in velocity over time.
Negative acceleration; slowing down over time.
Input threshold below which values are ignored (common for gamepad sticks).
Time delay before an action can be performed again.
System that manages different states and transitions between them (e.g., idle, walking, jumping).
A mathematical quantity with both magnitude and direction.
A 2D vector with X and Y components.
A 3D vector with X, Y, and Z components.
The length or size of a vector.
A vector operation that produces a vector perpendicular to two input vectors.
A unit of angle measurement (2π radians = 360 degrees).
A unit of angle measurement (360 degrees = full circle).
Calculating intermediate values between two known values.
Moving a value toward a target by a fixed step amount.
A normalized vector indicating which way something is facing or moving.
The rate of change of position over time (speed with direction).
Resistance that slows down movement when surfaces are in contact.
A constant downward force applied to objects.
An instantaneous force applied to a physics body.
A continuous push or pull applied to a physics body over time.
The remainder after division (e.g., 7 % 3 = 1).
A mathematical function that defines a smooth path or transition.
Sine function; produces wave-like values useful for oscillations and rotations.
Cosine function; produces wave-like values useful for rotations and oscillations.
Tangent function; ratio of sine to cosine.
Random or pseudo-random values used for procedural generation.
A type of noise function that produces smooth, natural-looking random patterns.
A distinct condition or mode that a game object or system can be in.
A system with a finite number of states and transitions between them.
A hierarchical decision-making structure for AI, using nodes and branches.
A shared data storage system used by AI systems to share information.
Artificial Intelligence; systems that control non-player characters.
The process of finding a path from one point to another, avoiding obstacles.
A navigation mesh; a data structure representing walkable areas for pathfinding.
A point in space used as a navigation target or checkpoint.
AI behavior that guides movement toward a target while avoiding obstacles.
A system that tracks elapsed time and triggers events after a duration.
A centralized system for broadcasting and receiving events across the game.
A design pattern where objects subscribe to and react to events.
Publish/Subscribe pattern; a messaging system where publishers send messages to subscribers.
A class that ensures only one instance exists throughout the application.
A design pattern where dependencies are provided to objects rather than created internally.
Converting objects or data structures into a format that can be stored or transmitted.
A system that persists game state to disk for loading later.
A saved game state that players can return to if they fail.
Creating and placing a new game object into the world.
Removing a game object from the world.
Reusing objects instead of creating and destroying them for better performance.
Automatic memory management that frees unused objects.
When memory is allocated but never freed, causing gradual memory consumption increase.
Measuring performance to identify bottlenecks and optimization opportunities.
Finding and fixing errors in code.
A point in code where execution pauses for inspection.
Recording information about program execution for debugging and monitoring.
Collecting and transmitting data about game performance and player behavior.
Analysis of collected data to understand player behavior and game performance.
